related_questions.question: Who discovered myocarditis?
related_questions.snippet: Myocarditis was discovered as heart disease at autopsy with the use of microscope. In 1900, Carl Ludwig Alfred Fiedler first reported with the name of acute interstitial myocarditis a sudden heart failure.
related_questions.title: Story telling of myocarditis - ScienceDirect.com

related_questions.question: Where does myocarditis come from?
related_questions.snippet: Myocarditis is most commonly caused by a virus, such as the flu or Covid-19, or another viral infection. If you're worried, you can read more about the effect of Covid-19 on the heart, including how it can cause myocarditis.
related_questions.title: Myocarditis - causes, symptoms & treatments - BHF

related_questions.question: Can you live a long life with myocarditis?
related_questions.snippet: Your prognosis with myocarditis depends on how severe your symptoms are and how inflamed your heart is. Many people can live for years without problems after treatment for myocarditis. Others may need to keep taking medications. There's also a small risk that you'll develop myocarditis again.
related_questions.title: Myocarditis: Symptoms and Causes - Cleveland Clinic

related_questions.question: What was the incidence of myocarditis before COVID?
related_questions.snippet: The latest Global Burden of Disease statistics before the COVID-19 pandemic place the worldwide prevalence of myocarditis and cardiomyopathy at 10.2 to 105.6 cases/100 000 individuals. A recent study estimated pre-COVID myocarditis in the United States at 1 to 10 cases/100 000 individuals (Table 1).
related_questions.title: COVID-19, Myocarditis and Pericarditis | Circulation Research

text_blocks.snippet: Myocarditis was first described in the mid-1800s, with the term "myocarditis" being coined in 1837 by Joseph Freidrich Sobernheim. However, it wasn't until the late 19th and early 20th centuries that myocarditis was clearly distinguished from other heart conditions and its distinct characteristics were identified through microscopy and autopsy.

list.title: Early descriptions (mid-1800s):
list.snippet: The concept of heart muscle inflammation, though not yet specifically named myocarditis, began to be recognized.
Joseph Freidrich Sobernheim introduced the term "myocarditis".
Carl Ludwig Alfred Fiedler (1835-1921) described acute interstitial myocarditis, noting inflammatory cells in the heart muscle at autopsy.
Sergei Semionovich Abramov published an autopsy case of myocarditis with cardiomegaly three years before Fiedler.
The work of Fiedler and others, including Christian Georg Schmorl, helped to differentiate myocarditis from other heart diseases and to identify different inflammatory histotypes.

The World Health Organization and the International Society and Federation of Cardiology defined myocarditis as an inflammatory disease of the myocardium, diagnosed by established histological, immunological, and immunohistochemical criteria.
